awd_titl_txt: Workshop Series on Thermal Issues in Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change is one of the most important issues of our time. The consequences of a changing climate have implications on local and global economies and human health and can exacerbate existing inequalities. Researchers in the thermal community have contributed significantly to providing engineering solutions to climate change, including improved heat transfer mechanisms for higher efficiencies, the food-energy-water nexus, and advanced material and flow behavior for renewable energy. This award is to support a series of virtual mini-workshops on thermal issues in climate change that bring together researchers from the thermal community to nucleate and promote interdisciplinary collaborations and to collectively tackle this grand challenge. The outcome of the mini-workshops includes a roadmap for how the thermal community can work to address climate change and its societal impacts, with both short- and long-term items for implementation. The series will strengthen a community of researchers that collaborate across institutions and fields, and will provide professional development opportunities, particularly for junior colleagues, with a focus on including members of historically under-represented groups.

The goal of this virtual series on thermal issues in climate change is to facilitate collaboration through biweekly discussion sessions that bring together multidisciplinary researchers to find intersectional areas for advancement. Each session will revolve a topic central to the impact or prevention of climate change, and feature four to six speed talks of no more than three minutes apiece, followed by a brief general discussion and breakout rooms to delve more deeply into both potential collaborations and specific topics of interest that might evolve into future funding opportunities. For each session, there are fundamental questions underpinning the ability of the research community to address these focus areas. For example, thermal-electrical energy storage is a crucial technology in decarbonizing the current grid, as well as addressing space conditioning needs, but the underlying thermophysical phase change mechanisms of the advanced materials that can accelerate its adoption are still not well understood, including the conjugate modes of heat transfer in an active bed and the dynamic controls needed for precise operation. Beyond the advancements in discrete topics in science and engineering, the discussion series will also aid in communication between researchers at different institutions and fields, which will contribute to the thorough identification of key research and development needs for addressing climate change. The published outcomes of the discussion series will further this goal beyond the bounds of the series itself as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A virtual workshop series, "Heating Up, Cooling Down: Thermal Issues in Climate Change," was held on a bi-weekly basis during the Fall of 2021. Many of the researchers in the thermal community have focused on aspects of the climate change problem and potential solutions for years, including improved heat transfer mechanisms for higher efficiencies in energy systems, the food-energy-water nexus, and advanced material and flow behavior for renewable energy. However, it is important to think even bigger, and look at more interdisciplinary collaboration to tackle even more significant aspects of this challenge. That was the outcome of this workshop.

A strategic committee, comprised of ten researchers from different universities, was assembled, and six focus areas were chosen that addressed key areas of intellectual merit for thermal issues in climate change. Those areas are Making Things, with a focus on heavy industry, and the production of cement, steel, plastics, etc. (sub-topics: decarbonizing heat; making cement; manufacturing commodity plastics; moderate to high temperature thermal storage); Plugging In, with a focus on electric generation from conventional, renewable, and other alternative perspectives/sources, as well as distribution and storage (sub-topics: high to very high temperature thermal-electrical storage; thermal and soiling management in PV; high temperature working fluids and storage; alternative thermal energy conversion processes); Growing Things, with a focus on agriculture, including plants and animals (sub-topics: heat transfer and FEW; new approaches for making fertilizers; agricultural by-products for plastic replacement); Getting Around, with a focus on transportation, including planes, cars, trucks, cargo ships, etc. (sub-topics: thermal management in batteries; heat recovery and conversion from engines; alternative fuel sources); Keeping Warm and Cool, with a focus on commercial, residential, etc. HVAC&R/climate control/primary energy consumption and reduction (sub-topics: low temperature thermal storage; decoupling of cooling and dehumidification; localized heating and cooling; alternative, zero-GWP cooling processes; building envelope); Earth's Energy Balance, with a focus on stratospheric and tropospheric responses/interventions to reduce temperature and carbon loads (sub-topics: passive terrestrial radiative cooling; active terrestrial radiative cooling; tropospheric aerosols).

For each workshop topic, four to six speed talks of no more than three minutes apiece were given, which were then followed by a brief general discussion and breakout rooms to delve more deeply into both potential collaborations and specific topics of interest that might evolve into future funding opportunities. For each topic and sub-focus area, participants identified items for implementation in the very near term (<2025), near term (<2030), long term (<2050), and very long term (<2100). At each focus area meeting, there were more than 60 attendees (some meetings had over 100 attendees), and the speakers and moderators worked together to lead the targeted discussions.

The broader impacts of this workshop series are clear: climate change is one of the most important societal issues of our time. The consequences of a changing climate have implications for local and global economies and human health, and can exacerbate existing inequalities both within the U.S. and around the world. Additionally, organizers, panelists, and attendees from a wide range of backgrounds presented at and attended the sessions. Although the majority of the participants were from the U.S., a number of international researchers also participated (most notably from Switzerland, the UK, India, and Japan). ﻿Justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion are crucial components in addressing the effects of climate change across a wide range of populations, nationally and internationally, and must be considered when examining existing problems and potential solutions. Finally, this workshop series provided professional development opportunities, especially for junior colleagues. Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers were particularly invited to participate.

In summary, this workshop provided a platform where participants were able to exchange ideas, collaborate, and develop plans for research impacting climate change across disciplinary boundaries.
